Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on . Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are
obtained prior to employment from persons
unrelated to the employee and which are less
than 12 months old.
One of twelve new employees hired did not have three dated references
completed prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the
person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect.
The documentation shall be completed not
more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Two of twelve new employees did not have a central registry clearance
completed within 30 days prior to hire date.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 8/24/23
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following

information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of
the employee’s performance annually thereafter.
One of twelve new employees did not have a performance evaluation completed
within 180 days of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours per
week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from
communicable tuberculosis shall be verified within
the 1 year period before employment and shall be
verified every 1 year after the last verification or
prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Two of twelve new employees did not have a TB test prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 8/24/23
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff
person whose function is covered by these rules
has participated in a minimum of 50 clock hours of
planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of
training annually thereafter related to the
employee’s job function. At least 16 of the 50 hours
provided in the first year shall be orientation
provided prior to the assumption of duties.
Five of twelve new employees did not complete 16 hours of orientation prior to
assumption of duties.
One of six employees hired for over 12 months did not complete 25 hours of
annual training.

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each resident
within 30 calendar days of admission.

(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an updated treatment plan for each

2 023 Interim, CAP approved 8/24/23
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within 14
days after discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation
of the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs
that remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the
parent and with the responsible case
manager.

One of two closed youth files reviewed did not contain a discharge plan.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 8/24/23
CCI Rule 400.4420 Food service facilities, equipment, and
procedures.
(1) Facilities, equipment, and procedures
used in the preparation, storage, and
service of food shall comply with the
applicable provisions of sections 12901 to
12922 of Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of
1978, as amended, being SS333.12901 to
333.12922 of the Michigan Compiled
Laws. The facilities, equipment, and
procedures required shall depend on the
amount of food service and the type of
food service operation.
The facility received a B-rating on their environmental health inspection
report as building C did not have any surface sanitizer present. Degreaser had
had been used on surfaces. Meat was being defrosted in water on kitchen
counter. Many open foods unlabeled and sponges present in sink. Agency
needs to confirm sanitizer present and procedure for labeling and thawing
posted on community refrigerator. Building B East and West had opened
food that was unlabeled and sponges present.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Staff training records must be kept up to date to ensure employee files can be
adequately and effectively audited.
• Environmental Health Inspection noted the ventilation in the bathrooms need to
be increased to avoid mold/mildew. Bathrooms 13A and 14 in building C had
excessive moisture. Some mildew present around shower and on curtain.
Ensure these bathrooms/showers are cleaned more often to avoid mildew and
mold growth.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require or request any consultation.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was investigated through SIR #2024C0000965SI dated 1/3/24. The
staff who was substantiated for threat of physical harm was terminated from
employment.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
- One CAP was from the 2023 Interim Inspection, which resulted in 7
licensing rule violations related to central registry clearances, TB
testing, physical exams, initial treatment plan, unsigned treatment
plans, and lack of a discharge plan. The CAP included the facility
creating and utilizing a new hire process form, retraining hiring
managers, retraining & tracking physical exams for youth, tracking due
dates for treatment plans, reviewing policy requirements for treatment
plans and discharge plans. The violations for employee records are for
both TLC and Ridgeview programs, but the violations regarding youth
files are strictly for TLC. The CAP was ineffective as 5 of those rule
violations are repeats for this Renewal Inspection. Additional corrective
action planning is required to address the continuous citations.
- One CAP was from SIR #2023C0000769SI dated 10/20/23. There was
a violation for Rule 400.4158(1)(a)(ii) due to a staff pushing a youth.
The facility implemented and completed the CAP successfully. The
CAP included reviewing restraint policy, implementing a coaching plan
with one staff, terminating the staff who pushed the youth,
implementing mental health first aid training for all staff, implementing a
special safety plan/de-escalation training for all staff, and ensuring staff
continue to attend CPI training as required.
- One CAP was from SIR #2024C0000965SI dated 1/3/24. There was a
repeat violation for Rule 400.4158(1)(a)(ii) due to a staff pushing a
youth. This was a different staff than the previous investigation. The
facility implemented and completed the CAP successfully. The CAP
included terminating the staff who pushed the youth, reviewing restraint
policy, reviewing/retraining on the self-awareness/de-escalation quick
guide, staff continuing to attend CPI training, and a hands-on retraining
for de-escalation.
- One CAP was from SIR #2024C0001035SI dated 1/29/24. There was a
violation for Rule 400.4127(4) regarding bed checks and ACT 116

722.120(1)(c) regarding falsification of bed check logs. The facility
implemented the CAP successfully and has continued to send quarterly
compliance updates as requested. The CAP included supervisors
completing weekly random video reviews and observation logs,
retraining staff on requirements for bed checks and falsification (initially
and annually), and discussing requirements/providing discipline during
supervision with staff as required.
Financial Overview
The facility's 2024 financial budget and Bethany Christian Services' 2023 financial
audit were reviewed. There were no concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The MDHHS Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA) compliance monitoring report
was completed on 12/15/22 and the facility was found in compliance with all
standards. The facility also received a certificate of completion for compliance
monitoring for December 2022-December 2023.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted the facility continues to improve compliance in
multiple areas. CA hopes 100% compliance can occur now that the facility has a
newer program director, new assistant program director, new supervisor, and new
case management supervisor for the TLC program. CA noted the new hire and
transfer hire checklists implemented in February should resolve violations related
to employee files. CA noted hiring a new case management supervisor for TLC
should resolve the violations related to youth treatment plans and discharge
reports. CA noted there were a significant number of youth admitted during this
period of review who had increased levels of trauma. As a result, they challenged
rules, were destructive, struggled with basic program compliance, were abusive to
staff, and ultimately created an unsafe environment. CA noted, at times, the
behaviors of these youth adversely impacted staff’s ability to perform job duties.
CA noted they intend to separate TLC to a different license and plan to begin the
process in July 2024.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff feel the training they receive is relevant but can be repetitive. Staff feel
supported and love their roles. Even through transitions of management at TLC,
staff expressed feeling supported and know who to go to if there are concerns or
issues. Staff feel the policies and procedures are adequately communicated but
feel there needs to be more transparency regarding “why” policies and/or
procedures might be changed. Staff feel the transparency would make them feel

like communications about the changes are about building relationships rather
than forcing compliance.
Youth reported staff treat them well and care about them. Youth reported they get
enough food, and the food is good. Youth reported they feel safe at the facility.
Some youth at Ridgeview feel there are youth who are unsafe due to their
behaviors but feel staff quickly and adequately intervene.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility occurred during the inspection on 6/5/24. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the
inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
July 18, 2024
